title: Rugby World Cup 2019: Wales vs France result, quarter final scores
text:
Rugby: France have made a blistering start to their quarter final clash with Wales and the try to Charles Ollivon showed all the excitement the French are famous for.

Wales is through to the semi-finals of the Rugby World Cup after one of the most thrilling, controversial knockout games in the history of the tournament.

In a hugely dramatic second half Wales executed the second biggest comeback ever seen in the knockout stages of the Rugby World Cup and it was only secured on the back of a controversial strip which appeared to travel forward into a Welsh player’s hands.

The game was also turned on its head when Sebastien Vahaamahina became the first player to receive an instant red card at the tournament since 2011 when he clocked a rival player with a deliberate elbow to the face.

France was ahead 19-10 before the red card changed everything.

Wales finally broke the French defence with a stunning driving play in the 74th minute.

Camped in France’s 22m, Wales couldn’t crack the stubborn French line, until they overturned a scrum with a brave charge.

The Welsh pushed France back from the scrum with a huge push just 5m out from the try line and then forced the error with a stripping tackle that saw the ball pop up into the lap of a Welsh player, who was tackled just centimetres short of the try line.

From the next phase, Ross Moriarty, the man who was earlier yellow-carded, barged his way over.

The TMO reviewed the play to see if the strip had carried the ball forward, but the on-field decision was allowed to stand despite the ball appearing to drift slightly forward.

However, Vahaamahina red card brain snap was overshadowed by the dramatic final try that allowed Wales to finally break the brave French defence.

Replays showed the ball travelled marginally forward from a stripping tackle before Wales picked up the loose ball on the full and scored the decisive try on the next phase.

France was devastated after bravely defending with 14-men for more than half an hour before the controversial strip finally broke their backs.

Wales now goes through to a semi-final against the winner of the Japan-South Africa blockbuster after an unforgettable 20-19 victory.

Vahaamahina’s moment of madness where he was sprung elbowing Aaron Wainwright across his jaw nine minutes after half-time proved to be the thing that cost France a spot in the final four.

He was called out by the referee and shown a red card, leaving France with 14-men for the final 32 minutes of the game.

“That is deliberate, on purpose and some of the worst foul play I think we’ve ever seen,” Wales former international Tom Shanklin told the BBC.

He is just the third player to be shown a red card in the history of the knockout stages of the World Cup and the first player since the 2011 World Cup.

Ouch.... Red cad for the French after this effort from Sebastien Vahaamahina 🤷‍♂️

The most stupid, reckless foul play of the World Cup has earned Vahaamahina a red card and opened door for Wales comeback #WALvFRA — Gavin Mairs (@GavinMairs) October 20, 2019

Vahamaaina is some class of idiot. What a completely stupid thing to do. #WALvFRA — Fionn Davenport (@fionndavenport) October 20, 2019

France players were devastated at full time after holding firm for 35 minutes where they were pinned in their own red zone under immense pressure from the Welsh attack.

For Wales, there was only the sheer joy of victory, hard won.

Still haunted by the memory of a stinging 9-8 semi-final loss to France eight years ago, the Six Nations champions looked decidedly uncomfortable until Vahaamahina’s rush of blood undid all of France’s hard work.

Defeat also brought the curtain down on France coach Jacques Brunel’s two-year spell in charge of the three-time World Cup finalists.

Vahaamahina had stunned the Welsh by bundling over from a lineout after just five minutes before France scored one of the tries of the tournament.

Roared on by chants of “Allez, Les Bleus!” flanker Charles Ollivon stormed through to complete a sweeping move involving Virimi Vakatawa, Romain Ntamack and scrum-half Antoine Dupont.

Back came Wales in an electrifying opening 12 minutes as flanker Wainwright pounced on a loose ruck on halfway to race clearfor his first Test try.

Biggar slotted a penalty to bring the Six Nations champions to within two points.

But when a high tackle from substitute Ross Moriarty on Gael Fickou resulted in a yellow card, France made Wales pay as Damian Penaud released Vakatawa to grab France’s third try on the half-hour mark.

French playmaker Ntamack struck the post with a penalty just before the break but the pendulum swung towards Wales after Vahaamahina’s rush of blood.

Caught on camera recklessly swinging his elbow flush into Wainwright’s face, it was only ever going to result in a red card.

His dismissal came as an ironic twist as then Welsh captain Sam Warburton received an early red card for a dangerous tip tackle on Vincent Clerc in that 2011 semi-final in Auckland.

Wales, who had won seven of their last eight games against France, were still made to work for it in a nail-biting finish.

But just when France looked like holding out for a famous victory, Moriarty popped up after a monstrous Welsh scrum.

Making up for his earlier indiscretion, the replacement forward bulldozed over six minutes from time before Biggar kicked the conversion that broke French hearts.

— with AFP
description: Wales is through to the semi-finals of the Rugby World Cup after one of the most thrilling, controversial knockout games in the history of the tournament.
